Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement Grant: "U.S. Veterans:" Two Fronts of Veteran Care among the Oglala, Lakota

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Historically, American Indians have had the highest per capita rate of military enlistment of any ethnic group in the United States. Pine Ridge Reservation, South Dakota, is home to thousands of Oglala Lakota veterans and many Oglala view military participation to be a central component of Lakota society. Yet nowhere is veteran care more at risk than within Native communities. In addition to persistent conflicts over Indigenous self-determination and cultural recognition, Oglala veterans often face hardships associated with poverty, illness, substance abuse, and geographic isolation. This project seeks to understand how the highly regulated domain of state authority represented by the United States Department of Veterans Services (the VA) interfaces with the cultural practices and practical realities of Indigenous communities. By comparing veterans of different periods -- World War II, Korea, Vietnam, Iraq, and Afghanistan -- the research also provides a lens through which to examine the complex and ever-changing relationship between federal governance and Indigenous life.

This research will contribute to a science of the complex modes of interface that connect different levels of governance with local life wherever it is lived. Data will be gathered in southwest South Dakota, on the Pine Ridge Indian Reservation and in nearby border towns. For over a century, Pine Ridge veterans have been served by the VA hospital in a border town to the west. A proposal has been made to consolidate this hospital with a more distant facility. The hearings, documents, and conversations around this proposal provide the researcher a venue in which to document and analyze the multi-faceted practices that Oglala veterans have developed for seeking effective governance, appropriate management of care, and self-determination. The researcher will employ a mixed methods approach, including life histories, semi-structured interviews, surveys, and archival research. Computer-enabled qualitative text analysis software will be used to produce a rich understanding of veteran life in a historically important tribe. This will supplement the statistics of poverty, illness, and violence that so often accompany descriptions of life on Pine Ridge. The research will also provide information for communities and policy makers committed to improving the fit between administrative expectations and a particularly vulnerable but poorly known population.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Frederick Howard worked for over fourteen months with Lakota veterans of the United States military living on the Pine Ridge Indian Reservation in South Dakota. Field research was conducted for the completion of the dissertation “‘Us Veterans’: Two Fronts of Care Among the Oglala, Lakota,” which focuses on the ways highly regulated governmental authority interacts with the cultural practices and practical realities of Indigenous communities in the United States. Specifically, the investigator examined the cost-benefit analysis of the closure of a Veterans Affairs hospital (VA) in Hot Springs, a border town of Pine Ridge, and the perceived inequity with which this analysis was carried out.

Research goals were achieved using a number of methods designed to gain an ethnographic sensibility of life on Pine Ridge and its border towns, including formal interviews, participant observation, and informal interactions. Research was primarily conducted in collaboration with residents and administrators of a homeless shelter for veterans on Pine Ridge. The investigator drove veterans from their residences on the reservation to their hospital appointments at the VA, at times over one hundred miles in each direction. He also provided transportation to and participated in a number of community events, powwows, and veteran organizational meetings. Additionally, Howard worked alongside veterans in community outreach efforts and observed public protests regarding Veterans Administration policies affecting Oglala veteran care.

The investigator examines the necessities of veterans’ healthcare and service benefits, while contextualizing these requirements within the cultural and political environment of Pine Ridge, as well as the settler colonial history of the United States. The statistical rendering of Pine Ridge’s population in terms of poverty and access to healthcare is well identified. This research qualitatively describes the human relationships and political contingencies that underpin these data, with a particular interest in the experiences of Lakota veterans, whose lives are considerably affected by federal Indian policy and the bureaucracy of the Veterans Administration.

Preliminary findings of this research indicate that assessments made regarding veteran care for residents of Pine Ridge only superficially consider the exceptional status of Native American reservations in the United States. When Oglala veterans return home to Pine Ridge after service, they return to a cultural and political community recognized by the U.S. Constitution as having existed prior to Euro-American settlement. Per capita, Lakota men and women enlist in the U.S. military at a higher rate than the general population. This research finds that a number of Lakota veterans view enlistment as a fulfillment of their treaty obligations to the United States. In turn, they expect the United States government to meet their obligations to the health and welfare of the reservation.

To be cared for as a veteran is to be recognized as a custodian and protector. In their conscription, they are guarantors of Oglala sovereignty. In this way, military service can be viewed as an expression of Lakota political identity. Though the hospital in Hot Springs is a federal facility located within traditional Lakota territory, it is an institution that serves to anchor and nourish this extraordinarily significant social role. The practical retraction of veteran care away from Native communities is then interpreted on a political register as a retraction from treaty obligations, as a disavowal of the Lakota veteran, and, furthermore, as a perceived continuity of colonial dispossession enacted through United States and Native American relations.
